columns.text: In this exercise, we need to find the value of the Fixed Assets of The Maurer Company.

We know the following values:
|||
|--|--|
Long-term Debt Ratio 	|0.35|
Current Ratio 	|1.3|
Current Liabilities 	|$955|
Sales	|$7,210|
Profit Margin	|8.30%|
ROE	|17.50%|

The first step is to find the value of the Current Assets (or short-term assets) and the Net Income with the values we already have.

First, we will calculate the Current Assets using the Current Ratio formula.

$$\begin{aligned}
 \text{Current Ratio} & = \dfrac{\text{Current Assets}}{\text{Current Liabilities}}\\
\\
 \text{Current Assets} & = \text{Current Ratio} \cdot \text{Current Liabilities}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Then we will calculate the Net Income using the Profit Margin formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
 \text{Profit Margin} & = \dfrac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}}\\
\\
 \text{Net Income} & = \text{Profit Margin} \cdot \text{Sales}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Know we use the new data calculated to calculate the Total Equity of the firm using the ROE (Return on Equity) formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
ROE & = \dfrac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Equity}}\\
\\
\text{Total Equity}& = \dfrac{\text{Net Income}}{ROE}\\
\end{aligned}$$

The following step is to use the Long-term Debt ratio formula to obtain the value of the Long-term Debt to add to the Current Liabilities to obtain the complete value of the Debt. This formula needs to be rearranged.

*First step:*
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term Debt Ratio} & = \dfrac{\text{Long-term Debt}}{(\text{Long-term Debt}+\text{Total Equity})}\\
\\
\frac{1}{\text{Long-term Debt Ratio}} & = \dfrac{(\text{Long-term Debt}+\text{Total Equity})}{\text{Long-term Debt}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

*Second step:*
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\text{Long-term Debt Ratio}} & = 1 +\dfrac{\text{Total Equity}}{\text{Long-term Debt}}
\\
\\
\dfrac{\text{Total Equity}}{\text{Long-term Debt}}& = \frac{1}{\text{Long-term Debt Ratio}} -1
\end{aligned}$$

So with that, we calculate the Total Debt.
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total Debt}&= \text{Long-term Debt}+\text{Current Liabilities}\\
&=\$1,841.32 +\$955\\
&= \boxed{\$2,796.32}
\end{aligned}$$

The Total Debt is **$2,796.32**

With the information that we have at this point, we can calculate the Debt-equity ratio to ultimately obtain the Equity Multiplier.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Debt-equity ratio}&= \frac{\text{Total Debt}}{\text{Total Equity}}\\
\\
&= \frac{\$2,796.32}{\$3,419.60}\\
&= 0.82
\end{aligned}$$

We know that the Equity Multiplier can be calculated as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity Multiplier} &= 1 +\text{Debt-equity ratio}\\
&= 1+0.82\\
&= \boxed{1.82}
\end{aligned}$$
The Equity Multiplier is **1.82**

The second to last step is to calculate the ROA (Return on Assets), with the ROE formula, so we can calculate the Total Assets value which we will use to calculate the Fixed Assets.

$$\begin{aligned}
ROE &= ROA \cdot \text{Equity Multiplier}\\
\\
ROA &= \frac{ROE}{\text{Equity Multiplier}}\\
\\
&= \frac{17.50\%}{1.82}\\
&=\boxed{9.63\%}
\end{aligned}$$

The ROA is **9.63%**

Now that we know the ROA we can calculate the Total Assets using the ROA formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
ROA &=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Assets}}\\
\\
\text{Total Assets} &=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{ROA}\\
\\
&= \frac{\$598.43}{9.63\%}\\
&=\boxed{\$6,215.92}
\end{aligned}$$
 
Total Assets are **$6,215.92**

Finally we can calculate the Fixed Assets value because we know the Total Assets is the sum of Current Assets and Fixed Assets.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total Assets} &=  \text{Current Assets}+\text{Fixed Assets}\\
\text{Fixed Assets} &=  \text{Total Assets}-\text{Current Assets}\\
&=\$6,215.92-\$1,241.50 \\
&= \boxed{\$4,974.42}
\end{aligned}$$

**The fixed assets will be $4,974.92.**
